ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: General overview of US Banking system - recent history, structure of banks, regulation, functions of banks in economic system etc.
Learned more about the way the banking system in the United States works.

Gained a much better understanding of the U.S. Banking System. Things like repo, executive compensation, mortgage-backed securities, bonds, and recent banking news were all discussed in-detail and I feel like I now have a decent understanding of how all everything ties together.
Lots of ways for banks to be regulated.

A lot of the syllabus overlaps with Metrick's Global Financial Crisis course, so if you've taken that you'll already know a lot of the material for this course. The main differences, besides being a seminar, are that this course has a broader scope (i.e. more pre and post GFC stuff) and covers more mechanical details of the banking system (so you'll do bond and repo math and learn more details about banking regulations).
Learned about the banking system and the recession

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Pascutti is awesome. Engaging and funny, with many interesting anecdotes. Class was very current and looked at things that happened in financial markets whilst the class was being taught.
Dont see how the course could be improved. Excellently taught.

The professor is definitely the strength of this course. Professor Pascutti is very engaging, caring, and charismatic, which makes this course a very unique one in all the economics courses I've taken at Yale. Another strength of the course is the material covered. I think the material is very relevant, especially for people going into finance. One weakness of this course is that it's sometimes a bit disorganized where quiz and test dates aren't decided until a few weeks before the quiz or test.
Hard course, but well taught and fairly tested
I wish I'd gotten feedback on my final paper, and but Pascutti is awesome and I really enjoyed this course.
I really loved this course-favorite course at Yale, I learned so much

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom was find but would have been better in person

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!
Easily One of the best classes I have taken at Yale.
Yes absolutely! The professor is amazing and you will learn a lot!
Yes! Even if you've taken GFC you'll get something out of it, and if you haven't taken / don't plan to take GFC then definitely take this class.
Yes! A must if you will work in finance

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/a
Live virtual lectures with some extra help sessions
